overview.short: Elizabethkingia species are Gram-negative, non-fermenting, aerobic, non-motile rods (often described as slender rods) found in water and hospital environments.
overview.clinical_context: Opportunistic pathogens associated with neonatal meningitis (historically E. meningoseptica), and bloodstream/respiratory infections in immunocompromised or critically ill patients.

field_notes.Oxygen Requirement: Typically strict aerobic and non-fermenting in routine lab descriptions.
field_notes.Oxidase: Commonly oxidase-positive, supporting placement among non-fermenting Gram-negative rods.
field_notes.Indole: Often indole-positive; this can be a useful clue in combination with oxidase positivity and non-fermenter profile.

key_differentiators.notes: Oxidase positivity helps distinguish from oxidase-negative non-fermenters like Acinetobacter and often Stenotrophomonas.
Indole positivity can help separate Elizabethkingia from many other common oxidase-positive non-fermenters.

common_confusions.reason: Related flavobacteria with overlapping biochemical patterns; definitive separation often requires MALDI-TOF or molecular methods.
Environmental Gram-negative rods with oxidase positivity and weak/variable biochemical traits.

when_to_question_identification: Oxidase-negative result makes Elizabethkingia less likely.
Clear carbohydrate fermentation pattern (multiple sugars positive) argues against Elizabethkingia.
Strong growth on MacConkey with typical lactose/non-lactose Enterobacterales pattern suggests misclassification.

recommended_next_tests.reason: Helpful clue within non-fermenting Gram-negative rods and supports Elizabethkingia when positive.
Most reliable for genus/species resolution among closely related flavobacteria.
